Why is the left so upset about Elon buying Twitter? Clearly this isn’t the typical liberal rage of being mad about pronouns or whatever the cause de jour is. There’s something more. 
  
Before Elon, Twitter was a mess. It was full of Chinese/Russian bots and run by an algorithm designed to promote the Regime Narrative (aka ‘The Current Thing’) while censoring opposing viewpoints. 
  
Then Elon buys it with the stated intention of cleaning it up & restoring ‘free speech’. 
 
Isn’t that what we want? A free marketplace of ideas with accountability & transparency?  
  
What are they afraid of? Misinformation? 
  
Having a marketplace of ideas is the best way to shine a light on misinformation. 
  
After all, not that long ago, telling doctors to wash their hands in between patients was considered misinformation.       
      
150 yrs ago saying that was as radical as saying Ivermectin can treat Covid.🤫 
      
And banning THAT speech is akin to banning speech about hand washing in the mid 1800s, which actually happened. 
  
Aren’t we more enlightened about science and freedom of ideas now than we were then? 
 
We should be. 
  
So why doesn’t the ruling class like Elon? It’s not because he is going to expose them. It’s even worse. 

It’s because he is going to allow the people to expose them. And that is their greatest fear.  
 
The Regime’s rage & resentment at Elon is not because they can no longer limit the reach of their ideological enemies, or due to “hate speech”, but because their ideas will have to compete. 
 
And the louder the Skittle Hairs & Regime Media screech the more confident I am that Musk is winning. 

Have you noticed the silence & cover from them on SBF? 
 
He was a billionaire that illegally played with other people’s money and lost it. Elon Musk is a billionaire using his own money to buy a social media platform to restore free speech. 
 
And the lefties are doing everything they can to stop & discredit Elon. What does that say about them? And their intentions?       
 
They know their days are numbered. They see their grip on power & control slipping. 
  
And in the end, it’s always about power and control. 
. 
.

There’s a certain line in a poker hand or airplane takeoff when you reach the ‘pot committed’ point and have to continue or it's dangerous.  
 
In pilot lingo, ‘V1’ is the point where you no longer have any choice.  
 
Before V1 you still have enough runway to abort a takeoff and stop before you run off the end of the runway.  
 
After V1 there isn't enough runway left to stop so you are committed to taking off. 
 
Even if you lose an engine, past V1 velocity you still have to take off and then do your best to land with one engine. 
 
Right now it feels like we’re at that point as a society. The acceleration of tech and the broader narrative has reached V1.  
 
We can't stop it. We can only hope to pilot tech and society in a way that keeps us alive until we figure out how to land it... 
⚔️⚔️⚔️⚔️⚔️⚔️⚔️

Now that the You Know What has stalled (only 15% of adults in the US are fully va_x_d), the Davos crowd has pivoted to Climate Change as the next global emergency. 
  
When it comes to the threat matrix, part of the risk calculus is weighing the likelihood of something happening against the magnitude of the event.  
  
And while I believe the likelihood of climate change being man made is somewhat low, I also believe our ability to impact the outcome without causing immense pain and poverty is near zero.   
  
When information is imperfect, assessing risk can be difficult. In such cases, we should choose the path that preserves optionality (keeps the most future options available).  
  
That doesn't mean we shouldn't strive to improve the quality of our air, water and increase renewables and battery storage power to take the stress off the grid and energy production. But it also means being realistic about our ability to impact global warming.   
 
Forget about Net Zero 2050. With our current tech, even an abrupt transition away from fossil fuels would be a low grade genocide by removing the most energy dense and powerful fuels in favor of unreliable and expensive 'renewables' like wind and solar.
  
Fossil and renewable fuel systems can run in parallel, but what the climate zealots miss is that fossil fuels power everything from transport to food production in the most economically efficient way, and it will be decades before that changes significantly.  
  
It is now well understood by most adults that the wide adoption of primary fuels with high energy density enables a better standard of living. Transitioning to higher density fuels is something that occurs spontaneously in an economy unless war or politicians interfere. In other words, we progressed to wood from windmills, coal from wood, petroleum from coal, and finally nuclear. 
  
What we’ve seen over the last few decades is an ugly reversal of this progress. Nuclear has all but been eliminated, and significantly more coal & wood will be burned this year than in prior years...

Merry Christmas and Happy Hanukkah to all of our friends and family.🖖🏼

May the lights of the season brighten all of our nights and lives. 🕎💙🎄

Merry Christmas and Happy Hanukkah!  
  
For many, the season is a time of hope and renewal, that brings to a close one year and the start of another. It can truly be ‘the most wonderful time of the year’ if you’re surrounded by people you love, with ample means to eat, shelter, walk and talk.  
  
For many, the season has high expectations and we end up feeling ‘less’ than we should. Tony Robbins has a theory that much of unhappiness stems from our gap between expectation and reality - but there's an easily achievable way out. By simply tempering your own hopes for accomplishments or perfect celebrations with family, you create room to appreciate those around us who may not have family at all or loved ones nearby - like members of the U.S Armed Forces spending Christmas overseas away from home - as well as anyone else hoping against hope for miracles this season related to health or finances.  
  
For others, they may be around friends or family, but acutely aware of the loneliness and depression that can come with this season.  
  
As someone who has struggled with both depression and addiction in the past, I want to offer a brief thought.  
  
Depression lies. It's like a malicious program that infects and interferes with the brain's operating system, convincing you to believe things that aren't true. Addiction compounds and exacerbates that lie.  
  
If you are fighting depression, there is help. If you are reading this, you have value and I am here for you. If you need to connect, just reach out. If you reach out, you will find that there are many hands reaching back towards you, including mine. 
 
The disconnect many of us feel is becoming more pronounced even as the technology around us improves at the pace of light. 
  
We have instant communication to any corner of Earth, and yet more people are lonely and depressed than at any time in history. 
  
We have pervasive always on social media, and yet too much of ‘social media’ is anti-social. We’ve become a society that is connected all the time and yet most online relationships/interactions are a mile wide and an inch deep. Humans are meant to share and connect IRL…

Austrian-born economist Joseph Schumpeter's pioneering insight painted capitalism as a behemoth of ceaseless reinvention, with new markets and products continually disrupting the status quo. He popularized the phrase “creative destruction” - an apt metaphor for how economic progress works: today's successes become tomorrow's casualties in this dynamic cycle of innovation. 
 
Today we are in the process of witnessing a wholesale refashioning of the global and local economy. Re-shoring and AI will be the two big trends for the remainder of the ‘Roaring’ 20s driving disruption. 
Careers requiring deft manual manipulation or the human touch should remain safe. Additionally, many of today’s more knowledge driven jobs will still require a human to ‘guide’ and monitor the AI assistant so this may not be the total employment apocalypse that many are worried about. 
 
However, as I wrote several weeks ago, the speed of change will be brutal. After all, the industrial ‘revolution’ was a severe holistic shock and took place over an 80 year period. 
 
The majority of the AI transformation will occur over the next decade. Old school blue collar trade jobs should continue to do well. Trades like plumbing, welding and electrical work are beyond the scope of most AI for the time being. 
 
And from a cost/benefit approach, these jobs are looking better and better than college at a $350K total price package for a good private school. The so-called Green Transition also exacerbates the short supply of qualified electricians...

Dr. Martin Luther King 1963. 
 
His letter was like many of Paul’s epistles, written from jail, inside a Birmingham jail during a turbulent time when peace-makers were few and peace-breakers many. It was written on not just any weekend, but on Easter weekend.

He mentions:  
Saul/Paul of Tarsus 
Socrates 
Reinhold Niebuhr 
St. Augustine 
Martin Buber 
John Bunyan 
St Thomas Aquinas 
Martin Luther  
Jesus... 
 
The letter is rich in spiritual and religious imagery, citing great thinkers and sources from the Old & New Testament.  
 
How many students in the mainstream secular-progressive schools would even understand this letter? They’ve never heard of the references and the biblical framework is foreign to them.

How many of the sources he cites would be deemed old white men unworthy of study on today's 'woke' college campuses? 
 
Are Dr. King's writings and legacy even taught today amidst the racial grifters peddling 'CRT' with its belittling of character and elevation of pigmentation as the only dispositive value?

This letter harkens back to a time where knowledge of the Old and New Testament was commonplace - but may as well be Latin for all its relevance in today's education landscape. In an era that prizes victimhood over virtue, it serves us a reminder: maybe reinstating timeless truths is what will help our society reach Dr King’s vision best – not revising history or rewriting religious stories. 

Dr. King's refusal to accept the churches' complacency of modern conventions reflects an all-too familiar angst that Jews and Christians share today - feeling weighed down by conventional norms, which often subvert traditional values that have helped shape our society for centuries. Values like supporting nuclear families, viewing gender as nonnegotiable, and protecting children from social engineering or intrusive medical treatments are at risk in this fast moving world where maintaining status quo is valued over security. 

The entire letter is linked below. It's worth a read, especially with your children if you have them...and especially if they attend a government indoctrination public school.
 
https://t.co/n0HBm3Z3P7

Big day for my youngest yesterday. This was my blessing I shared with him at the ceremony: 
 
Phineas, my beloved son, in whom I am well pleased: 
 
You come from a long line of Kimelmans and Moskows who paved the way for you to be able to stand here today on the Bimah and celebrate your step from adolescence to adulthood. 
 
I say STEP, because today is just the beginning.  
 
There is no finish line in your journey of manhood. 
 
You should know this if you don't already - your family and forefathers....none of them were perfect. 
 
In fact, they were all highly imperfect…Just like all of us. 
 
But despite their flaws, what they did extremely well is LOVE their children and their parents...and when they met the many obstacles in their lives, they never quit or stayed down. 
 
They learned from their failures and kept believing in the best of themselves and other people. 
 
My wish and blessing for you today, Phin, is that you have that same grit and deeply decent heart that your grandparents all had and have. 
 
May you be fighters like your parents, who have endured trials and tribulations...literally...and kept  
moving forward no matter the outcome.  
 
May you embrace life to the fullest...and appreciate all the tremendous gifts of intelligence, humor and  
health that God has blessed you with. 
  
May you find your purpose and courage when called.  
 
May you operate with empathy...and show up every day with curiosity. 
 
May your actions support righteousness, and your light serve as a beacon for others. 
 
May you light yourself on fire one day, so people come from miles around to watch you burn.  
 
May you always remember this extraordinary day - and those who came before you and made it  
possible for you to stand here today as a Jew. 
 
And May God smile upon you and bathe you in his light. I love you my son.  
 
And I say all these blessings in his name. Amen. 🙏🏻💙

Claircognizant.     
    
Do you occasionally know things without any rational or logical explanation?    
    
Intuitives, empaths, and highly sensitive people are often able to sense unspoken truths and unseen realities. There is a name for this powerful gift of knowing– claircognizance.    
    
Whether it’s called intuition or gut reaction, that knowing feeling is often subconscious pattern recognition but science has also recently come to grips with the idea that the gut has it’s own intelligence.    
    
At the base level, there is a connection to energy. Different religions and cultures have different names for the phenomenon - whether it's Chi/Qi if you follow Buddhism/Taoism, the Force if you're a Star Wars fan, or Holy Spirit if you’re a Christian.... there is something unseen and unconscious in us that connects us on a supra-consciousness level that either pulls us toward or pushes us away from certain people, places and things.    
    
It’s the same 'triggers' that my old friends in AA would speak about...the experiences, memories, smells, sounds etc....that recall and create cravings and desires for certain types of behavior.    
    
Without getting too 'woo', I'm saddened that we're building towards a climax or vortex where there's no going back. Especially for my children, who will ultimately pay the price for our mistakes.    
    
Whether the coming maelstrom aligns with and can be termed a Fourth Turning, a multi-generational debt cycle or a political cataclysm, you don’t have to be a psychic medium (or Ray Dalio) to know we are sailing into the medieval, ‘Here Lies Dragons’ section of unprecedented waters...    🐲🐉

Well…A physical and mental challenge I flew in for this weekend derailed a bit on the physical side.  
 
The question I’m tossing over as I enjoy 3 hots and a cot is, “How do you square the personal credo, ‘Do Hard Things’ with the more practical advice of, “Don’t end up in the hospital or dead.”  
 
There’s no one size fits all answer, but I think Clint Eastwood’s Dirty Harry was on the right track when he said, “A man’s got to know his limitations.” 
 
After all, how can you push past physical or mental limits if you don’t even know where the line begins and ends?  
 
When I get out of here with my legs and kidneys fully functioning, a few of the (obvious in retrospect) lessons I hopefully learned are: 
✔️Consistency is key 
✔️Stretch, don’t break.  
✔️And taper up.  
 
Push from a 3 to a 5, maybe even 6 when conditions are right. But don’t go run a marathon when you’ve never run more than 2 miles or attempt to summit Everest when you struggle up 4 flights of stairs.  
 
And the older you get the more you have to listen to your body. My mind still thinks I’m 32, my body KNOWS I’m 52.  
 
My legs were cramping and giving out 1/5 of the way in. A combo of pride, ego and sheer willpower forced myself to finish.  
 
Probably not the right move considering my preparation and stage of my life.  
 
However, on the bright side, my CK levels were the highest in this hospital’s history. Normal is 55-170.  I clocked in at 134,000. The cartoon below is me getting that news…🤦🏻‍♂️☺️

Whether depositors of SVB get made whole or not, plan accordingly. If they don’t, and you have over $250K in deposits, you need to spread that risk among multiple banks or use one of the SIBs that the Fed would never let fail.    
    
See link in bio for a LIST OF THOSE BANKS and more info on the SVB collapse.     
    
While there is moral hazard to helping the uninsured depositors, the alternative is additional bank runs that destroy small banks but leaves the Fed’s favorite children, the TBTF banks in an even bigger position. 
    
Ultimately, fractional banking is a system set up to fail. Banks should be closer to utilities if they are taking customer deposits & prohibited from speculating with customer money or holding insufficient cash to redeem. 
    
Since the financial sector is the biggest donor class, it's unlikely there is political willpower to convert an entire sector from a high-margin Cantillon machine into low-margin, low-return utilities. 
    
TF, a simple 2 step approach is needed. 
    
First, excess deposits should be opted into an enhanced insurance system like MaxSafe where for a few extra bps, the entire deposit is insured. 
    
Second, regulators should require banks to hold a much greater % of their capital in cash. That will hurt margins somewhat, but tough sh*t. 
    
Banks have proven they are not good stewards of capital. If they want to speculate or position themselves where they are vulnerable to bank runs, do it in another entity. 
    
A bank account should not be a wager on the competence of bank mgmt or govt. A depositor should never have to ask the question, "Will my money be there tomorrow?" 
    
SVB, The GFC, & the record-setting inflation are all failures of government, not capitalism or free markets.  
    
SVB’s management was primarily responsible for this collapse and they will be deservedly wiped out, along with the equity and bondholders. 
  
But remember, the backdrop of all this is a system where a single entity (the Fed) controls the price of money and changed it from 0 to +500 in a matter of months setting up this collapse. These kind of failures do not occur in free banking settings where rates float freely.

The most important chart of the day is the Deutsche Bank’s CDS chart and the most important video is Chair Powell's terrible poker face.♠️
  
For those familiar with reading body language, take a look at the ‘tells' Powell exhibits when asked a question about the Credit Suisse deal. 
 
I'm going to simplify this tremendously, but healthy debt trades at 'par', or 100 cents on the dollar. When the debt starts trading lower, it's usually because there is some doubt about the firm’s ability to service its debt.    
   
CDS, or credit default swaps, are basically a measurement of a firm's 'health'. If the company or their bonds are 'distressed' (selling at a discount bc investors don't believe the company will be able to make the payments) then investors can purchase CDS to 'insure' against loss.  
  
Credit Suisse was trading at 240 before it went under. As you can see, DB credit default swaps spiking higher indicates an increased probability that DB will default on its debt.  
   
Every bank failure from Bear Stearns to Credit Suisse is telegraphed by investors rushing in to buy CDS.   
   
CDS are like the heartbeat of a market, and right now the readings are very unhealthy.    
   
To add gas to the fire, we watched UBS and the Swiss Govt bail out Credit Suisse last week to prevent a much wider and more serious meltdown of markets (CS was comparable to Lehman in size and exposure).    
 
While many breathed a sigh of relief at the rescue, it appears based on Powell's 'answer' that the CS deal might not be done.   
 
If it were to unravel, we'd be in for a lot more pain & failures in the global banking sector (the ugly truth is the financialization of the American economy and the interconnectedness of all these banks due to derivatives and other complex instruments is massive).    
   
All it takes is a loss of confidence for the whole game of Jenga to unravel.
   
In finance, confidence is paramount.

Of all the Zeihan fallacies, the one I find most obnoxious is the ‘imminent collapse’ from demographics myth that he has espoused for more than a decade.  

While I do think changing demographics will keep a lid on markets as Boomers go from the biggest investor class to the biggest asset redeemers, the idea that a population mismatch will ‘imminently’ end China, Russia, Germany & others is a dangerous fallacy. 

Zeihan conveniently moves the timing goalposts when his prior estimates turn out to be wrong. As a trader, I have a very different definition of imminent. 
 
Imminent means actionable, and if you’ve taken any course of action based on Zeihan over the last decade, you’re probably playing guitar in the subways for meal money. As a trader, you can get the direction right but the timing wrong and still be dead wrong, and vice versa. 
 
To be correct, you need to get em’ both - timing and direction.  
 
Zeihan’s timing is so laughably wrong as to render the whole bet incorrect and meaningless. 
 
Nevertheless, anyone making policy or investment decisions based on his demographic ‘death sentence’ for China and others due to a population collapse is going to regret it. 

First of all, the rate of decline is too slow to matter. Similar to the Climate Change Hoax, if you’re speculating about something that might happen in 50 years, it’s meaningless. 50 years from now, our world will look nothing like its current iteration. 

Whether it will be a new stone age or a technological utopia, the idea that ‘not enough young workers’ will doom these countries is silly. 

Even if society is exactly the same as it is today, robots and AI will easily replace the ‘missing’ youth. And because they don’t need to be fed like those pesky humans, China may actually end up in a better position. 

Sure it will expose the pension Ponzis that exist in almost every state, but that pyramid would crumble regardless. People are living too long and inflation is too rampant for the current system to ever provide retirement security. 

Ignore the prognosticators preaching population collapse. We’ll have to deal with bad actors like China on our own w/o some kick save from demographics.

In recent years, we have witnessed a remarkable resurgence in spirituality. This wave has taken various forms, but two of its most notable expressions are the revitalized interest in the teachings of God/Jesus, and the growing exploration of psychedelics as a means to achieve spiritual awakening.  
 
While at first glance these two paths may seem disparate, there is an underlying connection that speaks to the fundamental human quest for meaning, belonging, and transcendence.  
  
The contemporary resurgence of spirituality around God/Jesus is characterized by an openness to the divine that transcends traditional religious boundaries. A growing number of people are seeking a direct, personal experience of the divine, rather than relying solely on the doctrines of organized religion. The teachings of Jesus, with their emphasis on love, compassion, and inner transformation, resonate with those who seek a more intimate relationship with the divine.  
  
This renewed interest in God/Jesus is also accompanied by a reevaluation of ancient spiritual practices, such as meditation and contemplative prayer, which are known to facilitate deep, transformative experiences. These practices help individuals cultivate inner peace, self-awareness, and a sense of connectedness with the divine, fostering spiritual growth and understanding.  
  
The rising interest in psychedelics thankfully comes as we struggle as a society with depression, PTSD and addiction, but also as a means of spiritual awakening that reflects the human desire for transcendence and experience of the divine.  
 
Psychedelics have been used for centuries by cultures for their ability to facilitate profound mystical experiences, including feelings of unity, love, and connection to the divine.  
 
Scientific research supports the idea that these substances and others can produce transformative spiritual experiences, with studies showing that they can lead to improvements in mental health, well-being, and even changes in personality traits related to openness & spiritual growth.  
 
While the paths of God/Jesus and psychedelics may seem distinct, there are several key areas where they overlap…

Memorial Day is a time to mourn U.S. military personnel who have died while serving in the United States Armed Forces.

In light of that, to wish someone, especially a grieving relative, a ‘Happy’ Memorial Day never seemed the appropriate precursor. Perhaps reflective or grateful, but neither of those exactly flow off the tongue. 

Whatever you decide on, please make it meaningful above the hot dogs, beer and sunshine. 

Enjoy the weekend, but take a moment to honor those who served our nation and are no longer with us.

Personally, both my grandfathers (below) and my father were proud veterans. I strive each day to honor their sacrifices, aiming to fill the immense footprints they've left behind, through a life lived with a sense of purpose and dignity. I am fortunate to have shared the better part of my existence with these three remarkable men, profoundly impacted by the roles they played and the indelible marks they left on my life.

I am awash with gratitude for my present abundance, a glimpse of which lies below. I am thankful, too, for the tribulations I've weathered, for they've revealed a resilience in me that I was previously blind to and provided perspective on life's true essentials.

A sage, certainly wiser than I, once remarked, "Tomorrow is promised to no one." It is this truth that prompts us to cherish and celebrate today, for we are privileged to have this opportunity.

 By living our lives with unwavering decency, positivity and purpose, we commence the repayment of an enormous debt of gratitude we owe to our servicemen and women, both past and present. 

Our every breath, every step forward, is a salute to their indomitable spirit.

When it comes to parenting, fathers are the unsung heroes of an intricate symphony, a role that, while often under appreciated, is of unparalleled significance. So, let's dive into a few reasons that underscore why fathers matter. 
 
A father’s influence begins from the earliest chapters of a child's life, acting as the sturdy keel that guides the ship through uncharted waters. 
 
Studies have shown that children with involved fathers tend to fare better academically, show more emotional stability, and are less likely to indulge in risky behavior. Consider the example of a dad teaching his child to ride a bike. 
 
More than merely mastering balance on two wheels, it's a lesson in perseverance, courage, and the art of getting back up after a fall. 
 
Fathers also play a pivotal role in fostering a sense of self-esteem and security. 
 
Let's recall the joyous moment when a dad lifts his child up high, a triumphant routine that serves as a metaphor for the empowerment fathers provide. This seemingly simple interaction is, in fact, a powerful confidence-boosting exercise. 
 
Beyond that, fathers help shape a child’s view of the world and their place in it. They model respect, empathy, and accountability, offering a blueprint for relationships and interactions. 
 
A father demonstrating respect towards all people, for instance, instills in his child a standard for how to treat others and expect to be treated. 
 
In essence, a father's impact is profound, reaching far beyond the realms of biology. 
 
Their love, guidance, and support are not just a paternal duty, but the ingredients that help mold an emotionally healthy and well-rounded individual. 
 
Now, that’s worth more than a tie isn’t it?? 👴🏻

Success in the realm of executive coaching (or anywhere else) is a journey defined by three essential pillars: retrospection, present awareness, and forward-looking vision. This holistic approach underscores the vital importance of understanding one's past experiences, staying attuned to the present moment, and envisioning a purposeful future.

By embracing this threefold approach, we ensure that the upcoming year begins with a foundation of self-awareness, laying the groundwork for a future characterized by confidence and purpose.

Highlighting the importance of looking back is a fundamental practice. It's not just about reminiscing; it involves a thoughtful examination of one's past experiences and current situation, all while keeping an eye on future goals. 

Encouraging clients to assess both their positive and negative experiences allows them to gather valuable insights, avoiding the repetition of past mistakes and enabling a more informed approach to the future. 

Coaching clients in the art of reflection provides a much-needed pause, allowing them to distill essential lessons from their experiences and set a purposeful direction for their future endeavors.

If you'd like a free copy of my 2023 Reflection and 2024 Visioncasting guide, hit me with a “yes” in the comments and I'll DM it to you.
